data.title: GOVT: Still A Buy, But For Different Reasons
data.description:
The iShares U.S. Treasury Bond ETF (GOVT), launched on 02/14/2012 by BlackRock, Inc. and managed by BlackRock Fund Advisors, offers exposure to the entire U.S. Treasury curve, targeting Treasuries with 1-30-year maturities. It charges an expense ratio of 0.05% and manages about $33 billion.

Broad exposure to the Treasury market, as represented by GOVT, implies an intermediate-duration bias, which at this point is warranted. I initiated coverage of this ETF back in January, and I explained why it was a buy. I approached its attractiveness from a "yield sustainability" perspective. In this article, I am approaching it from the perspective of interest rate changes, as GOVT positions an investor to gain more from the upcoming rate cuts relative to other Treasury ETFs on a risk-adjusted basis.

Portfolio & Performance

The ETF is currently holding 212 Treasury securities, which are clustered around Treasury Notes that have intermediate-term maturities.

GOVT's 30-day SEC yield is currently 3.81%, and its effective duration is 5.76 years. This profile helps explain its performance in the past, as its sensitivity to interest-rate changes is moderate relative to an ETF like the iShares 20+ Year Treasury Bond ETF (TLT), but meaningful to behave differently than short-duration vehicles.

When GOVT was launched, yields were close to record lows as a result of the central bank's quantitative easing that followed the GFC. That's the reason that since inception and up to around 2018, the performance is insignificant; yields rose slowly from very low levels, so income power remained weak while rising rates acted as a driver of modest downward pressure on the fund's price.

Fast forward to 2020, when the Fed lowered the Fed Funds rate to practically 0% in order to bring stability to the markets and the economy; GOVT rose sharply due to the steep decline in yields.

After inflation rose to high levels in the following years, the Fed intervened again by aggressively raising the policy rate of interest. This was also steep enough for GOVT's price to tank in 2022.

Last, GOVT started recovering in late 2023 as it became clearer that inflation was falling towards the Fed's target and the central bank's rate hiking cycle was over.

In 2025, GOVT kept climbing higher in a consistent manner. TLT has outperformed it so far, but not consistently, highlighting the bumpy road of monetary policy fueled by new risks of inflationary pressure.

Opportunities & Risks

Speaking of which, inflation is one of the reasons that makes GOVT relatively attractive as opposed to long-duration vehicles. It remains sticky, as it started rising in late 2024 and resurfaced as a key issue during the summer. With CPI at 3%, meaningfully above the 2% target, the monetary policy path is tricky to forecast.

Compared with short-duration vehicles, however, GOVT appears to be more attractive as well. Along with a higher risk of inflation, the labor market is also at risk of becoming a serious issue due to its softening in 2025 so far. That biases the Fed towards cutting further, even though the timing is highly uncertain. In such a scenario, GOVT should outperform both short and long duration.

Growth is another tailwind for Treasuries. In the first half of 2025, GDP has grown by ~1.4% on an annualized basis as a result of a contraction in the first quarter and a recovery in the second. Tariffs must have played a role in that below-historical-average level of economic growth, on top of restrictive monetary policy over the last 3 years. Economic forecasters expect the trend to continue for some time. Although a recession is not the base case, the risk of one occurring is elevated, and along with soft growth, investors are likely to continue being defensive to a meaningful degree, favoring safe havens like Treasuries over equities.

There are, however, two main risks worth monitoring. The first is the scenario where inflation rises more dramatically in the near term than it has in the past 12 months. And second, fiscal policy implies that the budget deficit will remain wide; with the Fed not in QE mode, the issuance of intermediate-term Treasuries implies supply that the central bank will not be able to absorb, and this will apply upward pressure on yields.

Conclusion

This is not a time for a cash bias anymore, as rates are expected to come down faster now, and long duration offered by TLT offers a very early bet as the road will still be bumpy with inflation risk, as mentioned above. GOVT provides the sweet spot for fixed-income allocators.

Now, I am always open to challenging my views because being an ideologue in investing and trading can prove expensive. So if you have a different opinion, this platform is the right place to discuss both strategy and the various options with which we can position our portfolios. Go ahead and leave a comment below to let me know what you think.

Otherwise, please let me know if you found this article useful. It means a lot!

Thank you for reading.

data.title: Perimeter Solutions: Dilution Tamps Further Upside (Rating Downgrade)
data.description:
In my July article, I made the case that Perimeter Solutions, Inc. (PRM) was nearing a breakout. It did break out, and is now up ~54% since then. The core business is tracking my initial thesis around the fire safety business being less cyclical, and a bolt-on strategy mirroring TransDigm (TDG). On the other hand, the variable fees tied to advisory shares are set to rise alongside the stock’s performance. Given the dilutive effects of this arrangement, I think the risks and rewards are more or less in balance. I am, therefore, downgrading my rating to Hold.

Strong Quarter, Predictable Margins

Revenue in the Fire Safety segment (86% of total Q3 revenue) was up 9% to $273.4 million, despite a mild fire season in the U.S. I had covered the low correlation with fire activity before, so it wasn’t a big surprise. International retardant sales were a surprise. The 10-K does break up its international sales at 15%, but I had assumed they were mostly from the Specialty segment due to the Phosphorous Pentasulphide plant in Germany.

Management again didn’t share exact numbers, but they did mention that overseas sales were up about $5.5 million, adding roughly 2 percentage points to overall growth. Adjusted EBITDA margins expanded 200 basis points to 65% ($177.2 million), mainly due to the full-service model, which results in better cost absorption and a stickier customer base.

The Specialty Products segment was weaker by comparison. Revenue was up 15% to $42.1 million, but the segment’s adjusted EBITDA fell to $9.1 million from $12.9 million a year earlier. Management maintained ongoing problems and litigation with Flexsys, the plant operator, which may be prolonged and is likely to be a drag on performance.

Meanwhile, the IMS division continued to be a bright spot. It added four new product lines year-to-date and contributed $10.8 million of incremental revenue in Q3. The business is emerging as a scalable M&A platform that can absorb small industrial product lines and enhance them through Perimeter’s value-driver framework.

At a consolidated level, revenue rose 9% to $315.4 million, and adjusted EBITDA improved 9% to $186.3 million. Free cash flow came in at $193.6 million for the quarter, driven by seasonal working capital release. Overall, the quarter reinforced the thesis that Perimeter’s cash generation and margins are becoming structurally stronger and less dependent on the severity of any given fire season.

The USFS Contract

I looked up the old contract on USA spending, and it had obligated amounts of $264.7 million in 2024 and $309.7 million in 2025. Of the $574.9 million total, $409.4 million was spent. Now, 2024 was a record fire year, and 2025 was a milder season, and the total outlay averages to $205 million. The new contract averages to $224 million, given the ceiling of $1.1 billion over five years. I think the revenue from this contract will likely be lower than the ceiling amount. And it seems to me that the value of the contract lies in exclusivity that locks in Perimeter as the sole supplier and adds strength to its monopoly moat. It also provides flexibility to the USFS to expand prevention operations and provides the company a stable source of revenue over the next five years. The visibility is nice, but I prefer a conservative approach to re-rating this as a case for multiple expansion.

Rising Founder Fees And Dilution Risk

Based on the disclosure about the founder’s agreement, the fixed fee is 2.3 million shares per year, continuing through 2027. So, this represents a dilution of 1.55% on the 147.9 million shares outstanding. The variable fee, by contrast, depends on a few moving parts.

I calculated the average closing price for the 208 trading days this year, and it is $14.84. If I fill out the remaining trading days for the year at an average of $25, the projected average closing price would be $16.52. To follow the maths in the disclosure, we need to subtract the high watermark established when the variable fee was last made in 2021.

Increase ($2.89) = 2025 Average Price ($16.52) – Previous high watermark ($13.63).

The total variable fee in 2025 would be 18% of this increase multiplied by 157.1 million shares.

Fee per share = $2.89 x 18% = $0.5202.

Total potential 2025 variable fee = $0.5202 x 157,137,410 shares = $81,742,921.

Half of the distribution is required to be in stock, with the balance payable in cash or stock at the founders’ discretion. On its current market cap, the amount in its entirety represents a 2.6% dilution. I’d say this would still be fine, but the average closing price in 2025 was dragged down by lower levels earlier in the year. Let’s say the price on average is around $25 in 2026. In that scenario, the variable fee would climb to $239.8 million, or a 7.7% dilution on the current market cap.

Potential 2026 variable fee = (25 – 16.52) x 18% x 157,137,410 = $239,854,543.

If you consider the 4.65% dilution from the fixed fee (2025 – 2027), this nets to a 15% dilution without a potential variable fee in 2027 and a 0% return on the stock in 2026.

Valuation & Final Take

The valuation assumptions in my previous thesis turned out to be pretty conservative. The YTD adjusted EBITDA is already $295 million, whereas I had assumed about $312 million for the next twelve months. If you apply the YTD 20% growth rate to the final quarter, the run rate annualizes to $334 million. I have assumed about a 9% increase over that number for the next twelve months ($365 million). It’s based on the idea that even in a moderate fire year, the margin expansion from an all-powder footprint should offset the impact from the ongoing situation at the Sauget plant.

In the absence of dilution, I’d likely still maintain a Strong Buy rating and wait for more data in future earnings. But the dilution effects really tamp down the upside. A re-rating now depends more on some of the other catalysts, such as solid-state batteries, coming into play. I am therefore maintaining a hold rating for now.

data.title: VYMI: Foreign 4.3% Dividend Yield Made Cheap And Simple
data.description:
I often think of the Rockefeller quote "Do you know the only thing that gives me pleasure? It's seeing my dividends come in". What probably gives me even more pleasure is seeing my dividends come in from a variety of businesses around the world, operating in different countries, and paying me in different currencies. Good and solid dividend growth, in my view, is one of the better ways of building investment income that is protected from inflation, because even if the dollar weakens, these companies selling all over the world will convert their profits into whatever the market rate is to provide a growing level of purchasing power of all the things they are selling. For those who do not get as much pleasure from looking around the world for dividends, there are of course ETFs that make it easier than ever to buy a simple and cost effective package of these foreign dividend stocks, and collect their yields from a single ticker. The ETF I wanted to pick up and have a refreshed review of today is the Vanguard International High Dividend Yield Index ETF (VYMI).

I last reviewed VYMI in June 2023, when I compared it against Vanguard's other international dividend ETF that focuses more on dividend growth than high yield, the Vanguard International Dividend Appreciation ETF (VIGI). At that time, my conclusion was that I preferred VYMI over VIGI because of VYMI's significantly higher yield (=significantly deeper value tilt, and I believe in value), while still having enough of a screen on dividend growth. This quick chart shows how the total returns of the two funds have evolved since then.

Earlier in 2023, I also wrote what is still a very useful guide to what I believe are Vanguard's best ETFs to buy, though I find it worth mentioning here that VYMI and VIGI were not in that guide. That is because, in my view, these dividend focused ETFs are not "pure" to the original Vanguard idea of simply buying the total market at the lowest possible cost, as opposed to paying up for a dividend screened portfolio. That said, Vanguard still is a leader at doing even these strategies very well and at very low cost, so I still consider them to be a leader in this category.

In this update, I will focus on highlighting VYMI's current portfolio holdings, its prospects for continued dividend growth, and its main competitors. In conclusion, I will then explain who I think this ETF is for, and which type of account I believe it is best held in.

VYMI's Current Portfolio

Vanguard ETFs publish their holdings only quarterly, so these observations are based on what I see on VYMI's homepage dated September 30, 2025.

Geographically, VYMI is quite diversified with about 14% in Japan, 11% in the UK, 8% in Canada, 7% in Switzerland, and 7% in Australia, among the top 5 developed markets. Mainland Chinese stocks make up a little over 6% of VYMI, though Taiwan and Hong Kong respectively make up about another 4% and 2%, which adds up to an overall exposure of 12% to "Greater China", which also sounds about right. There are also +1% allocations to other interesting markets like India, Mexico, South Africa, Saudi Arabia, and Korea, so while I might want to see more of a tilt towards these more minor markets, at least some exposure is there.

In terms of sector exposure, the one big standout is that over 42% of VYMI is in financials. This may not be surprising given that in many foreign markets, financials are the largest, and in some cases, only dividend paying stock available in that market, and effectively act like a leveraged exposure to that country's credit market. While I would love to see international dividend ETFs separate financials and non-financials so I can do my own mix, for now, this is what we have. The next four largest sector weightings in VYMI are energy, industrials, consumer discretionary and consumer staples at about 7-8% each, so starting to look quite well balanced once we get past the financials.

As of this writing, the single largest reported holding is British-based and Hong Kong focused bank HSBC Holdings Plc (HSBC), which I first covered in 2017, and still hold some shares in today in a few client accounts. The next three holdings are Switzerland's top 3 giants Novartis (NVS), Roche (OTCQX:RHHBY), and Nestle (OTCPK:NSRGY), so even the #3 and #4 holdings in this ETF trade OTC on the US market, which is one reason many US investors might prefer them packaged in an ETF. Rounding out the top 10 are names most readers will be very familiar with: Shell, Toyota, Mitsubishi, RBC, CBA, and Allianz.

VYMI's Dividend: Past and Future

VYMI's reported dividend yield was 4.28% as of September 30, and would likely be about the same today as VYMI is up less than 1% over the month of October. That's only about 0.2% per year higher than the 10-year US Treasury yield (US10Y), so besides tax reasons (mentioned at the conclusion), the main reason to prefer VYMI over bonds is if you expect these dividends will not only not get cut, but will likely increase in the future. Below is the sum of dividends paid each calendar year since the fund's launch in 2016, showing an overall solid growth trend, even with plenty of fluctuation from year to year, much of which is due to currency fluctuations. Given the percentage of the portfolio invested in businesses that are likely to increase their dividends with inflation, I overall see this as a better long-term income portfolio than the 10-year treasury for many portfolios.

Year Sum of Dividend
2016 1.356
2017 2.1484
2018 2.4154
2019 2.6807
2020 1.9585
2021 2.8868
2022 2.8024
2023 3.0473
2024 3.2859
2025 (Q1-Q3) 2.3766

VYMI versus other International Dividend ETFs

VYMI is the largest non-US focused dividend ETF I am aware of at almost $13 billion in assets under management, over double that of the next largest with $6 billion, and the next three with about $2 billion each. Below is a quick YChart of these other four competing ETFs's relative assets under management, and rolling 5-year total returns, which I leave here with no further comment, as comparing these would deserve a whole different article. What I will mention here is that VYMI's expense ratio of only 0.17% is significantly lower than IDV's 0.49% and IHDG's 0.58%, but almost double the 0.09% charged by HDEF and DIVI. Of these two cheaper ETFs, HDEF focuses more on higher dividend yields, so its dividend yield is significantly higher than that of DIVI and closer to that of VYMI.

Conclusion

While VYMI is not the cheapest ETF focused on non-US high dividend stocks, it is the largest and overall has a solid portfolio, track record, and brand name. As with every ETF though, it's not for everyone, so I wanted to conclude by saying who it's for, where it's best to own it, and who it's not for.

VYMI could serve as a solid pillar in a portfolio primarily focused on generating dividend income, especially one that needs that dividend income to come from non-US sources to diversify away from US equity risk. In my view, it is ideally held in a US taxable account, as there it might be possible to claim foreign tax credits back from the foreign countries that withhold taxes on dividends paid out through this fund. I say more about foreign tax credits in this article, where I even say how to go even further with the idea for those who are really into maximizing foreign tax credits.

So who is VYMI not for? First of all, I think this ETF may not be the best buy for many non-US investors, as the US may withhold taxes on VYMI distributions over and above those already withheld by the foreign companies when sending their dividends to this fund. Second, I'd rather hold VYMI in a taxable account, and hold US dividend stocks in an IRA or tax sheltered account, in order to maximize the tax credit benefit, as mentioned already. Finally, I would also say VYMI is not for investors who don't need the income and instead want to maximise total return, as opposed to just income return. There is a whole other argument about dividends and total return, but for now, I hope this review has been helpful for those just wanting to see how well VYMI does its job of letting you see your dividends come in from dozens of countries around the world.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Wolverine World Wide Doesn't Deserve A Step Higher
data.description:
To be honest with you, I have never really been all that interested in anything related to the clothing and accessories industry. But there has been one exception in recent years. Since reading Shoe Dog, which is a memoir about Nike (NKE) co-founder Phil Knight, years ago, I have been interested in the footwear market. One company that plays in this space that I was previously bullish about is Wolverine World Wide (WWW). And since I originally downgraded it to a "Hold" in September 2022, the stock has indeed underperformed the market. But recently, financial performance has sent the share on a big leg, or I guess I should say foot, higher. In fact, since I last reaffirmed it as a "Hold" candidate back in May of this year, shares are up 73%, while the S&P 500 is up 21%. Clearly, the company is doing well. But in all honesty, this alone is not enough for me to change my overall assessment.

When you really take a step back and assess the company and look at how it's valued, you see a firm that is definitely not a value play. Yes, the firm's recent growth is encouraging. And it could pave the way for additional upside in the near term. But because of how the stock is priced on an absolute basis and relative to other similar firms, I maintain that a "Hold" rating is the most sensible approach. My assessment could change as new data comes in, and with management planning to announce financial results for the third quarter of the 2025 fiscal year before the market opens on Nov. 5, and with analysts expecting some solid results, the firm could be set to do well. But at the end of the day, remaining principled is important when it comes to investing. So unless I see new data justify an upgrade, an upgrade isn't going to happen.

Some stellar results

The newest data that we have regarding Wolverine World Wide covers through the second quarter of the 2025 fiscal year. The branded footwear company, which sells its products in somewhere around 170 countries and territories, and which operates 121 retail stores in key markets and 39 direct-to-consumer e-commerce sites, reported revenue during that quarter of $474.2 million. This represented an increase of 11.5% over the $425.2 million generated a year earlier.

This rise in sales was driven largely by a surge in revenue associated with Active Group. Overall revenue skyrocketed 16.2%, or approximately $49.6 million. According to management, this was thanks to the $42.3 million benefit that the company got from Saucony and a $15.2 million benefit from Merrell. This growth has been driven by a concerted effort by management to really promote these brands. For instance, the Run As One campaign that the firm launched earlier this year after management initiated a "strategic reset" last year and the year before aimed at divesting of non-core assets and making other major corporate changes, really helped to position this as a growth engine for the company.

The aforementioned campaign, which came out in early March of this year, focused on promoting things like global run club events, coffee shop residencies, and a multifaceted approach to advertising that included utilizing television, online, and a wide array of other forms of outreach to improve public awareness of the brand. As for Merrell, which is the firm's largest brand, its growth seems to have stemmed from a change in offerings to emphasize "faster, lighter, more athletic" product lines, with one example being the Moab Speed 2 that saw revenue almost quadruple year over year in the United States.

The overall jump in revenue for the company was aided by the Work Group, which reported a 2.4% increase in revenue amounting to roughly $2.5 million. This was only because of strength from its Cat, Harley-Davidson, and HYTEST product lines, while its Bates and hallmark Wolverine brands reported declines in revenue. Meanwhile, its "Other" category reported a 21.7% drop in revenue amounting to $3.1 million. But this was because of a hit that the company took to its joint venture and royalty revenue streams and lower sales associated with Hush Puppies and Sperry.

As revenue increased, profitability for the institution shot up. Net income skyrocketed from $14.2 million to $26.8 million. Other profitability metrics performed well also. Operating cash flow jumped from $26.7 million to $44.6 million. If we adjust for changes in working capital, the rise is even more impressive, from $2.6 million to $36.9 million. And finally, EBITDA for the business grew from $39.3 million to $47.7 million. In the chart above, you can also see financial results for the first half of 2025 compared to the same time last year. Overall, the picture for the business here looks positive.

Moving forward, there is a lot of uncertainty. In fact, management even mentioned that they are not at this time reinstating their 2025 annual outlook because of macroeconomic uncertainty. Although the company expects certain brands to do quite well, there are worries about the direction the economy is heading. And honestly, a good chunk of that worry seems to be associated with tariffs. When management announced results for the second quarter of 2025, they mentioned in their earnings call that the hit to the company should be around $20 million before any mitigation efforts. This is down from the $30 million initial impact that management had feared. In essence, what the company seems to be doing is working with suppliers to see if they can cover some of the cost increases. They are also reducing how much they are sourcing from China. In fact, earlier this year, somewhere in the mid-teens worth of their products came from that country. But now, that figure is less than 10%. Strategic price increases have also come into play. But given how weak consumer confidence is currently, I suspect that this could create some pressure on results moving forward.

If we project out results based on what we have seen already for this year, we would get adjusted operating cash flow of $140.9 million and EBITDA of $188.8 million. Using these estimates, we can see in the chart above how shares of the company are currently priced. These are multiples that put the company squarely in the fair value range, as I see it. And relative to other similar firms, that situation doesn't look much different. In the table below, I stacked Wolverine World Wide up against five similar enterprises. On a price-to-operating-cash-flow basis, two of the five firms were cheaper. And when we use the EV-to-EBITDA approach, that number rises to three.

Company Price / Operating Cash Flow EV / EBITDA
Wolverine World Wide 15.5 14.7
Steven Madden (SHOO) 16.7 18.9
Rocky Brands (RCKY) 7.1 7.8
Crocs (CROX) 5.8 5.7
Deckers Outdoor Corporation (DECK) 16.1 10.5
Nike 29.3 26.2

I did mention earlier in this article that management will be announcing financial results for the third quarter of 2025 before the market opens on November 5th. At present, analysts are of the opinion that revenue will come in at $461.5 million. That's 4.8% above the $440.2 million the company reported at the same time last year. They are also of the opinion that earnings per share will grow from $0.28 last year to $0.32 this year, taking overall net profits up from $23.6 million to $26 million. In the table below, you can also see historical results for cash flows for the third quarter of last year. I would wager that if revenue and profits both rise, then cash flows will grow as well.

Takeaway

Based on the data provided, I would argue that Wolverine World Wide is doing great fundamentally. But that does not always equate to a good investment opportunity. Shares of the company are certainly not cheap. If anything, they are barely in the fair value category. And even though recent growth has been positive, I worry about management's decision to not provide any guidance. When you add on top of this weakening economic conditions, it seems clear to me that a "Hold" rating makes more sense than a "Buy" or a "Sell" at this time.

data.title: Beef Up Your Portfolio: Top Stocks For Trump's Cattle Battle
data.description:
Argentinian Beef Plan Rattles Cattle Market

I recently wrote an article titled Beyond the Food Fight: Top Agricultural Stocks as Soybeans Soar, highlighting the high-stakes tensions impacting the food industry. Beef prices have soared in the past year, driven by high demand and a national cattle shortage – boosting revenue for producers while squeezing margins for companies downstream in the supply chain. In a bid to ease consumer prices, the Trump administration vowed to loosen tariffs on beef imports from Argentina, despite opposition from U.S. ranchers. To bolster cattle production, the USDA rolled out a plan outlining land management incentives, targeted grants and loans, and regulatory reforms.

In September, the price of ground beef was up about 13% year-over-year - rising roughly four times faster than headline inflation. Some experts doubt the Trump administration’s plans will reverse this trend any time soon. The U.S. raised the tariff rate quota on Argentine beef from 20K to 80K metric tons. Imports of the product from Argentina totaled 33K metric tons in 2024, about 2% of total beef imports. The new inflow would represent a modest increase compared to 13M metric tons (28.7B pounds) of beef used in the United States last year. Meanwhile, the USDA said herd rebuilding programs will take time to pay off. Even if major changes are unlikely in the near term, the announcements sent cattle prices tumbling this week. In addition to Argentina, livestock traders are watching potential U.S. efforts to import more beef from Mexico and Brazil.

Beef prices ripple through supply chains in different ways, with consumers usually feeling most of the pain. High prices have squeezed margins for grocers and restaurants. Distributors may struggle to fully pass on volatile input costs to customers. Beef producers have capitalized on the price increases to lift revenue. However, input prices have been rising faster than output prices in the past 12 months, so meatpackers are eager for policies that expand cattle supply.

There are solid stocks across the beef value chain that could benefit from the shifting price dynamics – and many have managed to navigate tariff and cost headwinds to deliver strong growth and profitability.

Top Stocks For Riding Beef Trends

SA Quant identified three stocks with "Buy" ratings, along with two bonus stocks with Quant Hold Ratings, in industries that potentially stand to benefit from changes in beef prices. The companies stretch across the supply chain from packing and distribution to retail and restaurants.

1. Tyson Foods, Inc. (TSN)

  • Sector: Consumer Staples

  • Industry: Packaged Foods and Meats

  • Quant Sector Ranking (as of 10/31/2025): 24 out of 180

  • Quant Industry Ranking (as of 10/31/2025): 4 out of 48

  • Market Capitalization: $18.29B

  • Quant Rating: Buy

One of the world’s largest meatpackers, Tyson produces about 20% of the beef, pork, and chicken consumed in the United States and features a product portfolio that includes popular brands like Jimmy Dean and Hillshire Farm. Tyson and three other meatpackers control about 80% of U.S. beef processing – an oligopoly that grants them strong pricing power, but soaring cattle and feed costs have compressed spreads. Tyson underperformed the sector in the last 12 months, although the stock saw a slight bump after beating earnings for the eighth straight time in Q325 and raising revenue guidance.

Tyson has delivered excellent overall growth in earnings, operating profit, and cash flow over the past year, outperforming the sector, earning an A- Growth Grade. In Q325, Tyson posted year-over-year growth in sales, adjusted operating income (AOI), and EPS for the fifth consecutive quarter, driven by strong performance in its prepared foods, chicken, and pork segments. Strong cash flow enabled Tyson to return $201M to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. Other key Q325 highlights include:

  • Revenue: $13.88B (+4% YoY)

  • AOI: $505M (+3% YoY)

  • Adjusted EPS: $0.91 (+5% YoY)

  • Leverage Ratio: 2.1x vs. 3.1x

The only soft spot was the beef segment, with cattle availability at record lows, restricting Tyson’s ability to fully capitalize on strong product demand. A double-digit rise in prices drove beef segment sales up 6.9% YoY to $5.60B, but lower volume and margins led to a $151M loss in AOI. Wall Street sell-side analysts still have high earnings growth expectations for FY25, with EPS expected to rise 22.4% in FY25 and revenue by 2.7% to $54.77B. Tyson is trading at 13.5x earnings and has a PEG FWD of 0.88 - a 65% discount to the sector, underpinning a B+ Valuation Grade. The company's valuation is boosted by a high-yielding, safe, and consistent dividend. Tyson’s dividend yields 3.89%, has a 3.55% 5Y CAGR, and has been paid out for 35 consecutive years.

The beef segment faces headwinds from rising input costs and the potential of Argentine imports taking market share, but Tyson could get long-term relief from government efforts to increase cattle capacity. Tyson has also been able to mitigate downside through product diversification, operational efficiencies, balance sheet discipline, and network optimization. Tyson’s strong growth relative to the sector, attractive valuation, and solid balance sheet make it a top SA Quant Buy in the packaged foods and meats industry.

2. McDonald's Corporation (MCD)

  • Sector: Consumer Discretionary

  • Industry: Restaurants

  • Quant Sector Ranking (as of 10/31/25): 58 out of 489

  • Quant Industry Ranking (as of 10/31/25): 1 out of 42

  • Market Capitalization: $215.82B

  • Quant Rating: Buy

McDonald’s buys more processed beef than any company worldwide and has faced inflation headwinds in the U.S. and international markets, although franchises have shown discipline in keeping price hikes to low single digits, remaining focused on affordability and value. Although lagging the sector, MCD is outperforming major fast-food rivals, aside from Yum! Brands, Inc. (YUM) in the past year.

Although classified as a consumer discretionary stock by GICS, McDonald's has traded like a defensive sector security and a go-to amid uncertainty, as SA Analyst Florian Muller observed while upgrading the stock to a Buy. MCD can help investors protect their portfolios from a potential AI bubble, according to Muller:

I can hardly imagine AI replacing your Big Mac or McDonald’s real estate in prime locations. As such, McDonald’s serves me well as a solid portfolio anchor amid emerging volatility… With its loyalty program supporting long-term stability, MCD is well positioned for both economic uncertainty and market fluctuations.”

MCD 1Y Performance vs. Major Fast-Food Peers

McDonald’s achieved positive comparable guest counts globally in Q225 despite industry challenges as it accelerated new restaurant development. McDonald’s is on pace to open a net of 1,800 new restaurants globally in 2025 (+4% YoY). Global system-wide sales grew 6% YoY, and global comparable sales were up by nearly 4%, driven by meal bundles, affordable pricing menus, and record sales for new product introductions like the Chicken Big Mac in Germany.

U.S. comparable sales grew 2.5% amid ongoing efforts to re-engage low-income consumers through offerings such as the $5 Meal Deal, the McValue platform, and the national relaunch of snack wraps. MCD posted 5% growth in EPS and continued to demonstrate strong profitability as it has in the past year, crushing the sector in gross profit, operating profit, and free cash flow margins.

MCD earnings are projected to grow ~4.68% in FY25 and revenue by 3% to $26.72B. McDonald’s has paid out a dividend for 48 consecutive years, including 48 years of growth. The dividend offers a yield of 2.46% and 5Y CAGR of 7.20%, although high payout ratios have negatively impacted its Dividend Safety Grade. The stock is trading at a substantial premium to the sector across the board, dragging down its valuation framework. McDonald’s offers robust profit margins, stability, and stands to gain if beef prices fall, making it the No. 1 quant-rated stock in the restaurant industry.

3. US Foods Holding Corp. (USFD)

  • Sector: Consumer Staples

  • Industry: Food Distributors

  • Quant Sector Ranking (as of 10/31/25): 16 out of 180

  • Quant Industry Ranking (as of 10/31/25): 2 out of 7

  • Market Capitalization: $16.49B

  • Quant Rating: Buy

USFD is one of the largest food distributors in the United States with a focus on the independent restaurant, hospitality, and healthcare markets, and has handily outperformed the sector in the past year. USFD has consistently posted solid growth in revenue and profitability, as well as market share gains, and is pursuing a huge move to boost that share substantially.

USFD 1Y Price Performance vs. S&P 500 Staples Sector (XLP) (as of 10/30/2025)

In August, USFD reached an information-sharing arrangement with Performance Food Group Company (PFGC) to explore potential merger synergies. While the two companies overlap significantly in restaurant, hospitality, and institutional foodservice, PFGC, which is currently a Quant Hold-Rated stock, could add a valuable foothold in specialty distribution channels such as convenience retail and vending. This broader offering is central to the merger rationale, as USFD CEO Dave Flitman explained in a statement:

We believe a combination would bring together the best of both companies, resulting in meaningful economies of scale, expanded growth opportunities, complementary geographic reach, operational efficiencies, and a differentiated go-to-market offering based on service excellence, industry-leading digital capabilities, and a strong, customer-centric salesforce.”

Deutsche Bank analyst Lauren Silberman believes the merger could unlock meaningful value creation, and the question remains the premium USFD is willing to pay.

Overall, we remain positive on both USFD and PFGC individually given attractive growth outlooks, while potential for strategic optionality with the deal represents further upside," added Silberman.

In Q225, USFD recorded its 17th straight quarter of market share gains with independent restaurants and its 19th consecutive quarter of market share gains with healthcare. USFD stated that the company offset a considerable portion of operating cost inflation in the quarter through productivity improvements and eliminating waste in the supply chain, along with greater process discipline across the business. USFD center-of-plate categories, including beef, actually saw moderate deflation in the quarter. Wall Street analysts have been bullish on USFD earnings potential, with 14 upward earnings revisions in the last 90 days to one downward revision. Earnings are projected to grow 23.7% in FY25 and revenue by 4.46% to $39.57B.

USFD trades at a premium to the sector at 18.7x earnings. Its PEG FWD ratio of 1.22 represents a 51% discount to the sector, reflecting a robust long-term EPS growth rate of 15.36%.

The next two stocks I’ve included as “bonus stocks,” as I typically do not highlight Quant Hold-Rated stocks, particularly when Wall Street analysts are revising estimates downward. However, both of these stocks could potentially benefit as beef controversies stew, particularly PFGC, should it merge with USFD.

4. Performance Food Group Company (PFGC)

  • Sector: Consumer Staples

  • Industry: Food Distributors

  • Quant Sector Ranking (as of 10/30/25): 30 out of 180

  • Quant Industry Ranking (as of 10/30/25): 5 out of 7

  • Market Capitalization: $15.22B

  • Quant Rating: Hold

PFGC shares rose in September after it entered the information-sharing agreement with USFD to explore potential synergies from a merger and have also outperformed the sector in the past 12 months.

PFGC 1Y Price Performance vs. S&P 500 Staples Sector (XLP) (as of 10/30/2025)

The company reported cost inflation at 4.3% in Q4 of FY25, largely due to beef and seafood price increases, while noting that the food distributor does not expect material tariff impacts, considering the majority of inventory is sourced from domestic suppliers. Q4 revenue rose 11.2% to $16.9B and EBITDA by 19.9% to $546.9M, while total case volume was up 11.9%. Annual net sales surpassed $63B, and bottom-line growth outpaced the top line, driven by improved business mix and margin focus. PFGC has delivered solid growth in revenue, EBITDA, and cash flow in the past year, although net income was down 22%, largely due to higher D&A and interest expense tied to recent acquisitions. PFGC is expecting to continue gaining share within a $560B serviceable market that consists of three segments: Foodservice (66%), Convenience (25%), and Specialty (9%).

According to consensus estimates, PFGC EPS is projected to rise by 15.4% in FY26 and revenue by 6.3% to $67.28B. PFGC is trading at high earnings and operating profit multiples, for an average Valuation Grade, but PEG FWD of 1.90 marks a 24.85% discount to the sector. PFGC stands to gain from less volatile commodity prices and has solid momentum and upside earnings growth potential. USFD and PFGC announce earnings next week - it will be interesting to see if they can provide updates on their potential merger.

5. Brinker International, Inc. (EAT)

  • Sector: Consumer Discretionary

  • Industry: Restaurants

  • Quant Sector Ranking (as of 10/31/25): 254 out of 489

  • Quant Industry Ranking (as of 10/31/25): 14 out of 42

  • Market Capitalization: $4.8B

  • Quant Rating: HOLD

Brinker International’s shares slid this week despite exceeding top- and bottom-line Q126 earnings expectations, with revenue growing more than 19% to $1.35B, driven by Chili’s strong performance offsetting Maggiano’s weakness. EAT has been beaten down in the past month, despite strong growth, profitability, and earnings revisions. Brinker’s Quant Rating fell to Hold about a month ago, dragged down by a weak Momentum Grade. A member of the PRO Quant Portfolio and an Alpha Pick, JPMorgan upgraded Brinker in early October, citing management’s continued reinvestment “to finally differentiate Chili's in a long commoditized – yet very important bar and grill segment.”

Chili’s comparable restaurant sales rose 21.4% YoY, largely driven by higher traffic and menu price increases. Higher beef costs tied to new tariffs were offset by strong sales leverage that helped to contain restaurant and labor expenses. Companywide, operating margins rose from 5.0% to 8.7% YoY. Brinker is already crushing the sector in operating margins and return on equity, driving an A Profitability Grade, and has delivered impressive growth in the past 12 months in revenue, profits, and cash flow. EAT has 14 upward earnings revisions and five down revisions. Earnings are projected to grow by 15% in FY26 and revenue by 6% to $5.73B.

EAT showcases a P/E ratio of 10.5x vs. the sector’s 16.8x, while PEG FWD of 0.74 represents a 54% discount to the sector. Brinker is also trading at attractive price/cash flow, EV/EBITDA and EV/EBIT multiples. EAT was hit hard despite strong financial results as market expectations continue to rise to lofty levels. EAT is a quant Hold but worth keeping an eye on - the only thing holding it back is momentum. EAT rounds out our list of stocks to watch as beef prices change.

Top Stocks to Beef Up Your Portfolio

Beef prices have surged to record highs amid a national cattle shortage. In a bid to combat rising prices, the Trump administration loosened restrictions on beef imports from Argentina and unveiled a plan designed to boost cattle production. Solid stocks across the beef value chain have benefited from the soaring prices, while others have managed to navigate tariff and cost headwinds to deliver strong financial results. SA Quant picked five stocks in industries that stand to gain from shifting beef price dynamics - including meatpackers, distributors, and restaurants. This includes three Buy-rated stocks with solid investment fundamentals and two beaten-down Hold stocks with strong growth and profitability but poor momentum and downward earnings revisions.

We have many stocks with strong buy recommendations, and you can filter them using stock screens to suit your specific investment objectives. Consider using Seeking Alpha's Ratings Screener tool to help find stocks that achieve diversification into desired sectors you like. Alternatively, if you're looking for a select number of Quant Strong Buy recommendations on a monthly basis, you might want to explore Alpha Picks.

data.title: SPLG: S&P 500 Dashboard For November
data.description:
About SPLG

This article offers a top-down analysis of the S&P 500 Index based on valuation, quality and momentum metrics across GICS sectors. It may also help analyze funds tracking the index, such as SPDR® Portfolio S&P 500® ETF (SPLG). SPLG is less popular than SPDR® S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY), but it is large and liquid enough for most investors and traders, with $95 billion in assets under management and an average daily volume of $728 million. Additionally, SPLG has a cheaper expense ratio (0.02% vs. 0.09% for SPY) and a lower share price, offering more flexibility for small investors.

Shortcut

The next two paragraphs in italic describe the dashboard methodology. They are necessary for new readers to understand the metrics. If you are used to this series or if you are short of time, you can skip them and go to the charts.

Base Metrics

I calculate the median value of five fundamental ratios in every sector: Earnings Yield ("EY"), Sales Yield ("SY"), Free Cash Flow Yield ("FY"), Return on Equity ("ROE"), Gross Margin ("GM"). All are calculated on trailing 12 months. For all these ratios, higher is better and negative is bad. EY, SY and FY are medians of the inverse of Price/Earnings, Price/Sales and Price/Free Cash Flow. They are better for statistical studies than price-to-something ratios, which are unusable when the "something" is close to zero or negative (for example, companies with negative earnings). I also calculate two momentum metrics for each group: the median monthly return (RetM) and the median annual return (RetY).

I prefer medians rather than averages because a median splits a set in a good half and a bad half. Capital-weighted averages are skewed by extreme values and the largest companies. As a consequence, these metrics are designed for stock-picking rather than index investing.

Value and Quality Scores

Historical baselines are calculated as the averages on a look-back period of 11 years for all metrics. They are noted respectively EYh, SYh, FYh, ROEh, GMh. For example, the value of EYh for technology in the table below is the 11-year average of the median Earnings Yield of S&P 500 tech companies.

The Value Score "VS" is the average difference in % between the three valuation ratios ((EY, SY, FY)) and their baselines (EYh, SYh, FYh). The same way, the Quality Score "QS" is the average difference between the two quality ratios ((ROE, GM)) and their baselines (ROEh, GMh).

VS may be interpreted as the percentage of undervaluation or overvaluation relative to the baseline (positive is good, negative is bad). This interpretation must be taken with caution: the baseline is an arbitrary reference, not a supposed fair value. The formula assumes that the three valuation metrics are of equal importance, except in energy and utilities where the Free Cash Flow Yield is ignored to avoid some inconsistencies. VS and QS are capped between -100 and +100 when the calculation goes beyond these values.

Score variations since last month:

Momentum scores based on median returns by sector:

Interpretation

A hypothetical S&P 500 median company is overvalued by 13% relative to historical averages since 2014. Its quality score is close to the historical baseline. We can translate median yields into their inverse ratios:

  • Price/Earnings: 26.25
  • Price/Sales: 3.10
  • Price/Free Cash Flow: 44.25.

Energy still has the highest value and quality scores among GICS sectors (it has been so since February 2022). Healthcare, consumer staples, and real estate are very close to their 11-year averages in valuation. Financials, communication and consumer discretionary are moderately overvalued. Utilities, materials, industrials and technology are significantly overvalued (by 18% to 26% based on my metrics).

SPLG has returned 21.1% in 12 months, while the median return of the S&P 500 is only 3.3% (reported in the table above) and the equal-weight average is 8.2% (measured on RSP). It means individual stocks across the board have not done so well as the S&P 500’s return suggest. The index has been significantly skewed by mega-cap companies over the last 12 months.

The table above is not only useful to calculate value and quality scores. It may also help spot companies with attractive value relative to their peers. For example, the EY column tells that a large consumer staples company with an Earnings Yield above 0.0450 (or price/earnings below 22.22) is in the better half of the sector regarding this metric. A Dashboard List is sent every month to Quantitative Risk & Value members with companies standing in the better half among their peers regarding the three valuation metrics. data.title: Valaris Limited: Years Of Underperformance Might Finally Be Over
data.description:
Investment Thesis

I’m typically not the investor that spends a great deal of time in the energy sector but when I come across a company like Valaris Limited (VAL) I get excited. Management is planning on bringing back some of its cold-stacked rigs to capture the positive price momentum that day rates are seeing right now.

If the market behaves like the last market cycle Valaris is well positioned to grow its adj. EBITDA by a substantial amount in the next few years. As an extra on the side its partnership with Saudi Aramco (ARMCO) through ARO Drilling could provide a significant EBITDA boost as the venture seeks to grow the current rig count of 16 to 30 before 2035. Valaris shows clear upside potential, given the amount, making shares a Strong Buy now. The recent Q3 report only supports the thesis of growing day rates and stronger operational performance.

5-Year Performance Comparison

To preface the rest of the article, I’ve compared the 5-year price performance of Valaris to three ETFs. Further down I’ll compare to specific peers.

The comparison was made to:

SPDR S&P Oil & Gas Equipment & Services ETF (XIS)

  • Well diversified ETF with the largest holding being Liberty Energy Inc Class A (LBRT) with a 6.46% weighting. It owns VAL as well, which makes up 4.52%, making it the 9th largest holding.

VanEck Oil & Services ETF (OIH)

  • A more niche ETF with more exposure to oil service companies specifically. Largest holding is SLB Ltd (SLB) at 18.6%. Like XIS it owns VAL as well as its 10th largest holding, accounting for 4.02%.

SPDR S&P 500 ETF (SPY)

  • The “gold standard” for comparing, at least for me. If you can’t beat it then join. Now largely tech heavy but good to value against as being in a potentially terminally underperforming sector like energy would be a drag on future portfolio growth.

From the comparison it’s clear that it would have been much better to start an investment in a broader sector ETF rather than specifically Valaris. It followed the others very closely but then fell off. I want to highlight that Valaris never outperformed these ETFs, except for the SPY at any point. So investors got the higher associated risk of holding a specific stock and less alpha during the past 5 years. Valaris also doesn't have a dividend, something both XIS and OIH has, providing between 1.7 - 1.9% annually. This isn’t an article to just compare VAL to broad sector ETFs, but I think it's worth raising the point — “would it be worthwhile investing in Valaris, when these lower risk, higher yielding equities have performed better?”. To that I would say, yes. The upside is there and I think the years of underperforming has meant the valuation is also more attractive at the moment.

Forward Growth Assumptions And Management Comments

What about the forward assumptions for the company? In most areas Valaris is expected to outpace the sector median. The one area where it's lagging is the EPS Diluted and EPS GAAP Diluted. Both show negative 35% growth over the next 12 months.

“As the market continues to tighten through 2026 and into 2027, we fully expect there to be positive pricing momentum in the market.”

Even if the management of Valaris sees optimistically on the growth of dayrates, which is perhaps the single largest contributor to how much revenues and earnings it can generate, the market anticipates it to fall.

YoY the total combined day rates actually decreased by $8,000. This mostly came from lower rates in Jackups, of which Valaris has 33. In the categories harsh and benign day rates fell sharply. It was only the strong growth in Floaters which helped offset this change from a year ago. The current fleet composition for Valaris looks like this:

Floaters:

  • Drillships 13 (10 active)

  • Semisubmersibles 2 (2 active)

Jackups:

  • Harsh Environment 10 (8 active)

  • Benign Environment 14 (7 active)

  • Legacy 2 (2 active)

Leased Rigs (Jackups)

  • Harsh Environment 1

  • Benign Environment 6

Day rates can be highly volatile but management is making the case that it can see a return to the prior peak that occurred in 2012 to 2014 when they reached $800,000 per day. Market utilization was incredibly strong at 99% but when prices plummeted, it dropped to 76% instead. NE, on of Valaris' peers for instance contracted one of its rigs in the Gulf for $618,000 per day. This is far above today's levels. Valaris is a little different since it wasn't the same as today back then. In 2019 it was created after the merger between Ensco and Rowan. Between 2012 and 2011 Ensco reported 53% higher revenues, 49% adj. EBITDA margin ($1.56 billion operating income + $558 million depreciation). Many of the contracts Ensco secured at this time saw day rates in the range of $450,000 - $530,000. The year after (Q3 2013) Ensco secured a long-term contract with a day rate of $648,000 for its ENSCO DS-7.

Arguable what set the rise in motion was the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon that occurred off the coast of the US in 2010. It set back drilling in the region and offshore drilling investments came to a halt, creating a shortage in the number of active drills. The structure is similar this time too with tighter market conditions where less rigs are available and demand is increasing. Of course the price later came down heavily from the peak the last market cycle, with the years between 2014 and up until now mostly hovering in the range of $200,000 - 300,000. That doesn't mean we can't capitalize as investors on this cycle, that is much of what this whole thesis is based on.

When asked about spot prices and the implication that utilization rates will have on them CEO Anton Dibowitz said this:

“based on the timing of startups of programs, we expect to be exiting 2026 with utilization of 90% or better.”

This again speaks to the fact that management sees a potential cycle peak occurring in the next few years. Is that the best time to be buying the stock? Most certainly not. Is there still upside to VAL if rates climb from here, potentially reaching $800,000 or beyond that? I think there could be a lot of upside yet to be fully priced into the stock, therefore my bullish conclusion.

Day Rate Growth Analysis And Implications On Future Revenues

Currently spot rates are around or a little over the $400,000 mark as seen in the Q3 report, for drillships that is. Semisubmersibles and jackups are far below that. Crucially, VAL has several cold-stacked rigs, bringing the total fleet utilization rate down to 48%. The current active fleet has an active rate of 63%, again for drillships. At the moment there are 3 cold-stacked drillships. When asked when the company might increase the number of active drillships, VAL's CEO responded with that these may be up and running in 2028

“I think ’28 is a reasonable assumption if I can be so bold. If, you know, our focus, as you said, is clearly on keeping our active fleet highly utilized.”

There are currently 10 active drillships but VAL expects it could increase this to 11 by 2028, which is the same year I’ve modelled out the market might be peaking. I’ve used the same peak as the last cycle of $800,000. Utilization rates tend to be at 99% during these peaks and revenue efficiency is high as well. I expect the day rates to fall in the following year quite drastically, similar to what the last cycle showed.

Jackups typically see about 30 - 40% of the spot price of what drillships have, so the peak here is around $280,000 instead during 2028 as I modeled using the middle range (35%). VAL already has a high utilization rate and high efficiency rate even as prices now are lower so I don’t expect them to shrink, but rather incrementally increase until then.

With ARO Drilling it's important to mention that this is a 50% partnership with Aramco. I’ve modeled similarly to the other segments but the important piece is the Adjusted EBITDA. This is split by 50/50 which is what VAL “takes home”.

ARO Drilling is rapidly growing its fleet and will be perhaps an underappreciated growth driver of VAL over the next decade. The CEO of ARO Drilling Mohamed Hegazi mentioned the company's plan in a 2023 interview.

“Our strategic plan involves adding 20 rigs to our fleet over the next decade. This will potentially lead to a fleet size of over 30 rigs. Our fleet, as of Q2 2023, consists of 15 rigs, but we expect to increase this number to 18 by early 2024.”

From the fleet report VAL released this last October its clear ARO has 9 rigs which are fully owned, which combined with the 7 leased by VAL brings the fleet size to 16. This is my baseline for all of the four years as I won’t make assumptions on when ARO adds more, as no clear roadmap has been published as far as I know. The 38% EBITDA margin is in line with its recent performance as well.

The “other” segment relates to ARO Drilling as well as its where VAL leases out rigs to the venture partnership. Typically you’d see the charter rate be between 10 - 25% of the day rate but since this is a special type of venture it's actually higher at 30 - 40% instead. I’ve gone with 35% to be moderate. These revenues aren't affected by utilization or by efficiency, it's a set base depending on the charter rate.

I’ve decided to use a 27% adj. EBITDA margin as it will act as a sort of base case seeing as its the TTM figure VAL has reported. I say it's the base case since I anticipate day rates to rise which would likely lead to adj. EBITDA margin growing as well. Operating expenses will stay the same but the increase in day rates acts as a flat revenue boost, which is why I think it's reasonable to expect the margins to rise from today's levels. But for the sake of staying reasonable, I'm using 27%, which still shows a large earnings potential for VAL over the next 4 years.

Key Tailwinds Supporting Higher Day Rates

The three main tailwinds that supports day rates actually continuing upwards from here and reaching the same or a similar price peak as in 2014 is this:

There is a structural undersupply of offshore rigs. Following the last market cycle, a lot of these rigs got cold-stacked and even more so during the pandemic. Several peers expect a rebound for offshore rigs in 2026. RIG CEO Keelan Adamson said:

“We’re going to see more of the active fleet being contracted and as we move out into the end of this year and into 2026, we’re going to see a lot more contracting activity and tendering activity for the out years of ‘26 and beyond.”

Noble Corporation (NE), another close peers said the same thing under their last earnings report not that many days ago.

“While we anticipate a moderately lower earnings and cash flow profile in H1(first half) 2026 compared to H2 2025, the foundation for an improving market and corresponding earnings inflection is well underway.”

So VAL is not alone in saying the market is primed for a rebound next year. The CEO of VAL went on in the Barclays interview to cite the tightening of supply as a key driver of price hikes. The cost of re-instating cold-stacked rigs is also quite high. Some reports from 2023 mentioned $80 - 90 million. The cost of then building drillships wasn’t feasible either and since we’ve had a more hawkish Fed, access to cheap capital has led to less rigs being built.

With shale gains on the path to plateau soon, a lot of companies are pivoting offshore instead. The Permian Basin for example has seen parts of it reach geological limits. Other areas are yet to be drilled but are predicted to yield lower. The best parts of the Permian is often said to be "Wolfcamp, Spraberry or Bone Spring". They have the best combination of thickness, TOC and rock quality. They're often referred to as Tier-1 wells. Newer areas like Yeso or Atoka have lower TOC and generally more variability, basically meaning some wells might be done whilst others are not. This leads to lower output or lower yield, compared to the more well established and utilized areas of the Permian.

This indicates the large oil producing region might have peaked. This supports the thesis that energy companies will pivot to offshore which still has a way to go before peaking. This is visible as backlogs have risen sharply in recent quarters. VAL now has a $4.45 billion contracted backlog, up from $3.1 billion in Q3 2023 and $2.2 billion in Q3 2022.

The third tailwind is that global oil suppliers are being conservative with production, keeping the price between $80 - 90 per barrel. Companies are focusing on returning capital to shareholders and the best way to realize this is by having stable and relatively high oil prices.

Current Valuation Put Into Perspective

I’ve calculated how VAL could hit $1.359 billion in adj. EBITDA in 2028 if the market cycle plays out like the last time. The last time, that being in 2013 and early 2014 the day rates surged rapidly, utilization rates peaked at 99% and many off shore companies posted record top and bottom line results.

At the current EV of $4.69 billion it makes shares look substantially undervalued. EV/EBITDA for the sector is typically in the 6-7x range. My 2028 estimate would put Valaris at an EV of $8.833 billion. If we combine and normalize the EBITDA over the next 4 years, as per my earlier models, the EV would be $6.212 billion instead (using $955 million normalized EBITDA). This seems more realistic. Based on today's EV this leaves an upside potential in the range of 30-35%.

If ARO Drilling manages to build out its fleet to over 20 by 2029 it could see the valuation going higher as it would mean a moderate increase in the EBITDA Valaris receives.

Risks

The success of this investment heavily relies on oil companies continuing to spend on offshore ventures and rigs, building demand and premium for companies like Valaris. Offshore projects typically have a tough time getting funding if the price of oil is seen as shaky or risking decline over the next decade. We saw during the past few years how OPEC+ was struggling keeping the price stable as Russia, one of the largest oil producers in the world, increased production levels to help finance its country. There is a risk of countries going “rogue” and not adhering to OPEC+ which would put downwards pressure on oil prices.

To capture new contracts Valaris needs to reactive cold-stacked rigs, not just drillships but jackups as well. This will be capital intensive and could constrain the company's balance sheet. Reactivating these cold-stacked rigs are also part of my revenue estimates, so if the company decides against this it would be reflected negatively in the future revenue assumptions I’ve made.

The Full Picture

Offshore is going to have its time in the spotlight soon and VAL is a great play on this. Its strong core operations with several 7th generation rigs make it a premium option, leading to higher day rates and realized revenues. The shift towards offshore is coming as there is a structural undersupply of rigs after years of cold-stacking. Coupled with high costs of reactivating it’s creating a perfect storm for prices to surge. I expect VAL will be able to very well capture this momentum. My model also puts shares at a very considerable undervaluation if prices peak in 2028. Rating shares a Strong Buy as I initiate coverage on this stock

data.title: Farlong Proposes $16 Million U.S. IPO Terms, But Valuation Is Excessive
data.description:
Farlong’s Financial Results Are Deteriorating

Farlong Holding Corporation (AFA) has filed to raise $16 million in an IPO of its common stock, according to SEC S-1/A registration information.

AFA sells Chinese herbal supplements from its product formulations.

The company's revenue base is small, losses are worsening, and its valuation expectations are excessive.

My outlook on the AFA IPO is to sell (avoid it).

What Does Farlong Do?

Walnut, California-based Farlong Holding Corporation was founded to develop a variety of traditional Chinese herbal products primarily in the United States via distribution platforms and offline locations.

Management is led by Chief Executive Officer Jackson Kwok, who has been with the firm since 2023 and was previously at TYC Genera Corp, a manufacturer and distributor of automotive replacement parts.

The company's primary offerings include:

  • Best Doctor Formula

  • A Pure Herb

  • ZEN Life Herb

  • ACA Herb

  • Dr. Herbal Well.

Most of the firm’s revenue comes from wholesale relationships, as the contribution pie chart shows here:

Farlong has booked fair market value investment of $4.4 million as of June 30, 2025 from investors, including KMA Trust and KML Family Trust.

Selling expenses as a percentage of total revenue have jumped as revenues have grown from a small base, as the figures below indicate:

What Is Farlong’s Market?

According to a 2025 market research report by Grand View Research, the global herbal supplements market was an estimated $42 billion in 2024 and is projected to exceed $90 billion by 2033.

This represents a projected CAGR of nearly 8.9% from 2025 to 2030.

The primary factors driving this expected growth are growing consumer health awareness and an increasing preference for natural remedies wherever possible.

Also, the chart below shows the historical and projected future growth path of the worldwide herbal supplements market through 2033 by product type:

The company is active in the United States, which accounted for around 26% of the global market and is further focused on the Chinese herbal supplement sub-market.

Major competitive vendors or industry players include the following firms:

  • Thorne HealthTech

  • Nestle Health Science (OTCPK:NSRGY)

  • Metagenics

  • Fullscript

  • Himalaya Wellness

  • Jarrow Formulas

  • Solgar

  • Nature's Bounty

  • Gaia Herbs

  • Herbalife (HLF)

  • Swanson

  • Nature's Way

  • Amway

  • Others.

The firm sells its products through its DirecTCM platform, online stores, e-commerce websites such as Amazon.com, TikTok and Walmart, and B2B wholesale in clinics or medicine centers as well as selectively through customers using its white label service.

The company had 75 active healthcare providers on its DirecTCM platform who see an average of 420 patients per month each.

Farlong’s Recent Financial Results

The firm’s recent financial performance is summarized as shown below:

  • Rising top line revenue from a small base

  • Falling gross profit and gross margin

  • Increasing operating losses and cash used in operations,

As of June 30, 2025, Farlong had $1.1 million in cash and equivalents and $4.5 million in total liabilities.

The company has generated free cash flow for the twelve months ended June 30, 2025, of negative ($2.2 million).

Farlong’s IPO Plan

AFA intends to sell four million shares of common stock at a proposed price of $4.00 per share for gross proceeds of approximately $16.0 million, not including the sale of customary underwriter options.

No existing or possibly new shareholders have indicated an interest in acquiring additional shares of the IPO, as described in the prospectus.

Company, shareholder (greater than 5%) and executive lock-ups will be for the standard six-month period after the closing of the offering.

Dilution in net tangible book value per share for investors in the IPO is expected to be $3.73, which is within the typical range for a company at IPO.

The company’s enterprise value at IPO (assuming no underwriter options) will approximate $163 million.

The float-to-outstanding-shares ratio (excluding underwriter options) will be approximately 9.1%, so the stock will be a low float stock subject to potentially higher volatility in open market trading.

According to Farlong’s most recent regulatory filing, it plans to use the net proceeds as follows:

approximately 31%, or $4.4 million assuming no over-allotment option is exercised, or $5.1 million if the over-allotment option is exercised in full, for general corporate purposes...

approximately 24%, or $3.4 million assuming no over-allotment option is exercised, or $4.0 million if the over-allotment option is exercised in full, for R&D, including research collaborations...

approximately 20%, or $2.9 million assuming no over-allotment option is exercised, or $3.3 million if the over-allotment option is exercised in full, to finance the marketing and operational expenses for direct-to-consumer channel growth, physician outreach, and market expansion...

approximately 18%, or $2.6 million assuming no over-allotment option is exercised, or $3.0 million if the over-allotment option is exercised in full, to upgrade our Company’s infrastructure...

approximately 7%, or $1.0 million assuming no over-allotment option is exercised, or $1.2 million if the over-allotment option is exercised in full, for international expansion...

(Source - SEC.)

The firm’s presentation of the company roadshow isn’t available.

Pertaining to potential legal exposure, leadership said the company is not presently the subject of any legal or administrative action that is likely to have a material adverse effect on its financial condition or operations. However, the supplements industry is subject to many claims and has a significant risk of legal claims.

The only listed underwriter of the IPO is US Tiger Securities.

Here is a table of relevant capitalization and valuation figures for the firm:
