Farlong’s Financial Results Are Worsening

Farlong is seeking U.S. public capital market investment to fund its general growth initiatives and working capital needs.

The company’s financials have generated increasing topline revenue from a small base, but dropping gross profit and gross margin and higher operating losses and cash used in operations.

Free cash flow for the twelve months ended June 30, 2025, was negative ($2.2 million).

Selling expenses as a percentage of total revenue have increased recently and its Selling efficiency multiple fell to only 0.2x in the most recent reporting period.

The firm currently plans to pay no dividends and will retain any future available cash and earnings for its growth and working capital needs.

Farlong’s recent capital spending history shows it has continued to spend on capital expenditures despite generating significant negative operating cash flow.

The firm’s growth strategy includes expanding its DirecTCM platform and products and investing in its R&D efforts.

The market opportunity for providing herbal supplements is large and expected to grow at a reasonably strong rate of growth through 2033, but the market is extremely fragmented and subject to legal claims.

Risks to the company’s outlook as a public firm include its "emerging growth company" and "smaller reporting company" status, which allows management to produce substantially less information to shareholders.

Many of these company stocks have performed poorly post-IPO.

The firm has material customer and supplier concentration risks, and management said it could not assure investors that this situation would change in the near term.

Farlong has extensive related party transactions, with more detail here.

As to valuation, Farlong is seeking a wildly excessive EV/Revenue multiple of around 195x on a small revenue base, a slowing growth rate and increasing losses.

My outlook on the AFA IPO is to sell (avoid it).

Expected IPO Pricing Date: To be announced.

data.title: Moderna: Focus On Cancer Vaccines, Not Buyout
data.description:
Moderna, Inc. (MRNA) surged due to media reports of the company in talks with a large biopharma over a potential deal or partnership. The biotech stock was recently trading near multi-year lows, not ideal for a premium buyout. My investment thesis turns ultra Bullish with the stock still trading at prices below the big CEO stock purchase, much less any buyout.

Significant Deal

STAT news reported Moderna was working with at least one large biopharma on a significant deal. The market has no details on the nature of the potential deal, yet the stock soared 14% on October 30.

The biotech just reported a promising vaccine failed in a late-stage trial and Covid vaccine sales aren't promising anymore. Moderna continues to slash costs, so the news of a potential buyout or a significant partnership was surprising.

The company still has a cash hoard of $7.5 billion and management forecasts having the cash to reach breakeven by 2028. Moderna has cut the cash costs to ~$5.1 billion for this year with further reductions to $4.2 billion in 2027.

Moderna continued to forecast a 10 product drug pipeline with the potential for a $30+ billion TAM. The CMV vaccine failure cuts the TAM slightly, but the cancer vaccines appear the area of biggest potential, especially with the recent research revelations.

Cancer Vaccine

As the Covid vaccine fades in importance, Moderna has long highlighted a list of other vaccines and therapies to build the business. One of the prime focuses was the mRNA-4157 cancer vaccine now in a Phase 3 trial for adjuvant melanoma, along with all of the other promising cancer vaccines in the pipeline.

The biotech reported solid Phase 2 results for the cancer vaccine showing a 75% recurrence free survival rate after three years. The vaccine compared favorably to a 56% survival rate when using Keytruda from Merck (MRK) alone.

The actual shocking news from last week was a study suggesting mRNA-based Covid vaccines from Pfizer (PFE) and Modena were effective in boosting the survival rates of patients with lung cancer. The study results were shocking due to the patients taking the vaccines for protection against Covid, not cancer related.

Analaysts from the University of Florida and the University of Texas MD Anderson researched 1,000 patients who received treatments for advanced skin and lung cancer treatments at MD Anderson between 2019 and 2023. The key is that patients received the mRNA vaccine within 100 days of starting immunotherapy with checkpoint inhibitors while further research might show even stronger benefits to patients receiving the mRNA vaccine within a 30-day window before or after treatment.

The results were a surprise bonus considering the current negativity towards vaccines from Health & Human Services. According to the research, patients with advanced lung cancer saw median survival rates nearly double, rising from 20.6 months to 37.3. The survival rates for metastatic melanoma were boosted from 26.7 months to 30–40 months with some patients still alive at the time of data collection.

Noteworthy, non-mRNA shots for pneumonia and the flu didn't provide any survival benefits. Also, patients with severe lung cancer are likely to be older and survival rates extending beyond three years might naturally run into other causes of death.

The timing of Moderna talking to a large biopharma on a partnership or buyout is interesting considering this impressive cancer data. The researches plan to validate the data in a clinical trial.

The personalized cancer vaccine market was targeted to reach $8.5 billion by 2034, but the data from the Covid vaccine research suggest personalized cancer vaccines might not be needed. Moderna had a target for the MRNA-4157 vaccine for the melanoma indication to reach the $1 billion sales level, but the market might just have turned a whole lot bigger.

The U.S. is now spending upwards of $100 billion on anticancer therapies with ongoing annual increases. With Moderna potentially having an already approved relatively inexpensive vaccine that works on cancer, a larger biopharma could definitely have interest in a partnership or buyout.

The stock trades at multi-year lows and has hit strong support at $25. The CEO bought $5 million worth of stock back in March at higher prices of around $31, so investors can actually acquire shares below the CEO purchase price.

Naturally, the risk is that this promising cancer vaccine data turns out to not prove related to the mRNA vaccines. The large biotech faces a massive cash crunch without a viable new drug to stem the sales dip from faltering Covid vaccine sales.

The stock only has a market cap of $11 billion with the large cash balance, but sales are forecast to slip below $2 billion this year.

Takeaway

The key investor takeaway is that Moderna is a bargain, if the cancer vaccines turned into key products. The surprise data from the Covid vaccine clearly increases the odds of a successful drug.

Investors shouldn't bet on a buyout or partnership, especially with the cancer vaccine data pointing to a potential hit drug in the future. Moderna is set to report Q3 earnings next week and investors will want to pay close attention to any new developments on that front.

data.title: No Data, No Problem: S&P 500's October Rally Defies The Government Shutdown
data.description:
Stocks logged their sixth consecutive month of gains. The S&P 500 (SP500) rose 3% in the first month of the fourth quarter, with star-lit rallies among the mega-cap tech glamor stocks. The Nasdaq 100 ETF (QQQ) added more than 5%, while domestic SMID caps struggled. The S&P MidCap 400 ETF (MDY) fell by less than 1%, and the Russell 2000 ETF (IWM) eked out a 2% gain.

International stocks held their own. The Vanguard FTSE All-World Ex-US ETF (VEU) tacked on 2% to close at a fresh all-time monthly high, despite a strong 2.5% rally in the US Dollar ETF (UUP).

As for bonds, the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note (US10Y) fell, then climbed, eventually settling not far from 4.1%. That resulted in a 0.6% positive total return for the iShares Aggregate Bond ETF (AGG).

Elsewhere, gold (GLD) was volatile. The precious metal soared to a record high, above $4,300 per troy ounce, but then corrected to under $4,000 before Halloween. Bitcoin (BTC-USD) investors were also spooked, amid generally heavy price action in the cryptocurrency space (IBIT lost 4%). Finally, the United States Oil Fund (USO) gave back 2%, as the energy complex remains well supplied.

QQQ Best in October, S&P 500 Strong, Bitcoin Retreats

Digging into the S&P 500 sector ETF performance view, Information Technology (XLK) stole the show. The largest group of SPX equities soared 6%, though it actually fell between the two most important earnings reporting periods on the afternoons of the 29th and 30th. Health Care (XLV) continues its comeback, though it, too, stumbled into month-end.

Weak were some cyclical-value sectors, such as Materials (XLB) and Financials (XLF). Concerns about the K-shaped consumer and corporate environment were borne out in price trends in October.

October Sector ETF Returns: Tech Led, Financials Weak

Now, here’s where we have to get creative. While markets keep trading, official U.S. government data has been hard to come by. In fact, it has been absent from the macro conversation for a month. Still, I’m going to present to readers the best alternative data sources to get fresh reads on the labor market, the consumer, and inflation. Let’s get to it.

First, I normally begin with trends in the employment situation. We haven’t received either the BLS establishment or household survey since early September. Alas, we can look to the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago for its new real-time unemployment rate forecast. It shows a 4.35% jobless rate. That’s low by historical standards, but above trough levels from three years ago.

The Chicago Fed Real-Time Unemployment Rate Forecast: 4.35%

Then last week, ADP launched its weekly National Employment Report Pulse. The latest data show U.S. employers added an average of 14,250 jobs per week in the four weeks ending Oct. 11.

In fact, we may be seeing a slight pick-up in the labor market since late July.

ADP Employment Report Pulse Shows Modest Job Growth

Then, according to Goldman Sachs, it’s estimated that seasonally adjusted initial jobless claims decreased to about 218,000 for the week ended October 25th.

That continues a trend of sanguine first-time applications for unemployment benefits.

U.S. Initial Jobless Claims Hovering Near 220k Per Week

With a jobs picture that appears to be not all that scary, the consumer is holding up...if we take the weekly Johnson Redbook Retail Sales report as gospel. During the shutdown, we do not have access to official U.S. Census Bureau retail sales clues, and I believe Johnson Redbook is the next best thing.

At +5.2% year-over-year, overall demand looks good. Perhaps we can thank higher-end income households for the steady spending trend.

Johnson Redbook +5.2% YoY

Onto inflation. Again, CPI and PCE are published by the federal government. Truflation, however, pins domestic consumer prices rising at a 2.44% annualized rate.

That’s concerning, but Jeremy Schwartz at WisdomTree Funds put out that group’s own “true” inflation gauge by replacing lagging Shelter CPI with on-the-ground housing and rental data. The result? U.S. inflation may actually be close to 2%.

U.S. "Truflation" at 2.44%

U.S. Inflation Using Real-Time Shelter Price Data Near 2%

Well, we actually did get the September CPI last week. It was calculated and reported so that the Social Security cost-of-living adjustment could be made.

Headline CPI is now 3% from 12 months ago, the highest rate since January. The core CPI rate is also 3% YoY.

CPI Rises to 3% YoY

So, how long will we have to make due with alternative data sources? According to online prediction markets, mid-November could be when the federal government reopens its doors.

Government Shutdown May Last Into Mid-November

The economy appears to be doing fine on its own, however. While a somewhat dated Q3 read, the Atlanta Fed’s GDPNow model pegs the U.S. expansion rate at 3.9%. Early calls for Q4 also point to healthy growth.

Atlanta Fed GDPNow Shows Q3 GDP Close to 4%

Given that backdrop, there’s a growing Fed chorus to take a wait-and-see approach to monetary policy and interest rate moves. Recall that the FOMC cut rates a quarter point once each in September and October.

Bond traders were expecting a third ease in December...before Fed Chair Jerome Powell took to the podium this past Wednesday after the rate-cut announcement. He poured cold water on the notion that a December ease was imminent.

A December Fed Rate Cut Is Not A Forgone Conclusion

While the Fed’s future moves are in flux, U.S. corporations are humming along with profit growth (at the aggregate level). The S&P 500 is expected to grow earnings per share by 10.4% this year and 13.7% in 2026.

Moreover, the current reporting period (for Q3) could be among the strongest top and bottom-line beat rates in recent memory.

S&P 500 EPS Growth Expected to be Strong through 2026

The Bottom Line

Stocks extended their winning streak in October, powered by mega-cap tech strength (thank you, AI) while smaller domestic names lagged. Alternative data suggest the labor market and consumer spending remain resilient despite the government shutdown halting official reports. With inflation trending near 3% (using the official CPI data) and solid corporate earnings growth, the Fed has ammo to pause and reassess before its next potential rate move.
